templates.name: Hal Higdon Novice 2 Marathon
templates.author: Hal Higdon
templates.description: Designed to fit comfortably between Novice 1 and Intermediate 1. For runners who may have run their first marathon and want to add mileage while training for their second or third marathons.

prerequisites: About a year of running background
Have run occasional 5-K or half marathon races

key_principles: Long runs are the key to the program
Run long runs 30-90+ seconds per mile slower than marathon pace
Every third week is a stepback week for recovery
Walking breaks are acceptable strategy
Rest is an important component
Consistency over perfection

long_run.description: Key weekend workout building from 8 to 20 miles
long_run.pace_guidance: 30 to 90+ seconds per mile slower than marathon pace, or comfortable conversational pace
long_run.notes: Can include walking breaks at aid stations. Better to run too slow than too fast.

pace_run.pace_guidance: The pace you plan to run in the marathon (e.g., 9:09/mile for 4:00 marathon)
pace_run.notes: Appears on Wednesdays in this program

easy_run.pace_guidance: Comfortable pace, may vary day to day. Tuesday after rest might be faster than Thursday after two days running.
easy_run.notes: Focus on covering the distance, not the pace

cross_training.description: Any other form of aerobic exercise using slightly different muscles
cross_training.notes: Best to avoid activities requiring sideways movements (tennis, basketball) as mileage builds. Can vary activities week to week.

rest.description: Complete rest day for muscle regeneration
rest.notes: Muscles regenerate during rest (24-72 hours between hard exercise). Can take extra rest days if needed due to cold, late night, sick child, etc.

adaptation_guidelines.scheduling_flexibility: Can skip occasional workout or juggle schedule, but do not cheat on long runs
adaptation_guidelines.modification_notes: If need more rest due to cold, late night, sick child - take it. Consistency over 18 weeks is key.
adaptation_guidelines.strength_training: If never done before, wait until after marathon. If experienced, can continue but may want to cut back on weights as long run mileage moves to double digits. Tuesdays and Thursdays work well after runs.
adaptation_guidelines.stepback_pattern: Every third week reduces mileage to allow strength gathering for next push upward

templates.name: Hal Higdon Intermediate 2 Marathon
templates.author: Hal Higdon
templates.description: A slight jump in difficulty from Intermediate 1. Three 20-milers toward the end instead of two. Higher midweek mileage and more serious weekend running.

prerequisites: Previously trained using Novice or Intermediate 1 programs
Ready to increase mileage and run workouts at faster pace

key_principles: Long runs are key, building from 10 to 20 miles
Run long runs 30-90+ seconds per mile slower than marathon pace
Every third week is stepback week
3/1 training strategy available for experienced runners (first 3/4 easy, final 1/4 somewhat faster)
Walking breaks acceptable strategy
No speedwork in this program - save for Advanced programs
differences_from_intermediate_1: Reach 20 miles by Week 11 (permits third 20-miler in Week 15)
Second weekend run at 5-10 miles at marathon race pace
Cross-training on Mondays instead of weekend

long_run.description: Key weekend workout building from 10 to 20 miles
long_run.pace_guidance: 30 to 90+ seconds per mile slower than marathon pace. Physiological benefits kick in around 90-120 minutes regardless of pace.
long_run.notes: 3/1 strategy optional: run first 3/4 at easy pace, final 1/4 somewhat faster (not race pace). Better to run too slow than too fast.

pace_run.pace_guidance: The pace you plan to run in the marathon (e.g., 9:09/mile for 4:00 marathon)
pace_run.notes: Most Saturday runs done at race pace, day before Sunday long runs

easy_run.pace_guidance: Comfortable pace. As weekend mileage builds, weekday mileage also builds. Run roughly same mileage during week as weekend long runs.
easy_run.notes: Focus on consistency and covering distance

cross_training.description: Aerobic exercise using slightly different muscles
cross_training.notes: Scheduled for Mondays. Avoid activities requiring sideways movements. Can vary activities. Helps recover after Sunday long runs.

rest.notes: Friday designated as rest day. Muscles regenerate during 24-72 hours between hard exercise. Can take additional rest days if needed.

adaptation_guidelines.scheduling_flexibility: Can skip occasional workout or juggle schedule, but do not cheat on long runs. Modifications okay but too many means not following program.
adaptation_guidelines.modification_notes: Weekend runs can be reversed (long on Saturday, pace on Sunday) but placed Saturday before Sunday on purpose - to tire you out so you don't run Sunday too fast.
adaptation_guidelines.cross_training_substitution: Can substitute aerobic workout for Monday or Wednesday running. Same duration as scheduled run. Don't make it hard workout. Friday not good for cross-training - need rest for weekend.
adaptation_guidelines.stepback_pattern: Every third week reduces mileage for strength gathering

templates.name: Hal Higdon Advanced 1 Marathon
templates.author: Hal Higdon
templates.description: Progressive buildup starting at 10 miles, peaking with three 20-milers. Includes one day of speedwork (hill repeats, intervals, tempo runs). Designed for hard-core runners willing to take it to the limit.

prerequisites: Familiar with speedwork - do NOT begin speedwork in marathon program if never done before
Background in this type of training
Advanced attitude and commitment regardless of speed, sex, or age
Not for first marathon - wait a couple marathons before attempting

key_principles: Long runs key, building from 10 to 20 miles (three 20-milers)
Run long runs 30-90+ seconds slower than marathon pace
More training at marathon pace (usually Saturdays before Sunday long runs)
Speedwork on Thursdays (hill repeats, intervals, tempo runs)
3/1 training strategy for experienced runners
Every third week is stepback
Do not run long runs at marathon pace - adds too much stress with speed sessions

long_run.description: Key weekend workout from 10 to 20 miles
long_run.pace_guidance: 30 to 90+ seconds per mile slower than marathon pace. Physiological benefits at 90-120 minutes regardless of speed. Better to run too slow than too fast.
long_run.notes: 3/1 optional: first 3/4 easy, final 1/4 somewhat faster (not race pace). Only if running controlled during first 3/4. Once every three weekends maximum.

pace_run.pace_guidance: The pace you plan to run in marathon (e.g., 9:09/mile for 4:00 marathon)
pace_run.notes: Most Saturday runs at race pace, day before Sunday long runs

hill_repeats.description: Hill training scheduled every third Thursday
hill_repeats.workout_structure: Select ~1/4 mile hill. Run up hard (like 400m track repeat). Jog back down. Repeat until finished.
hill_repeats.pace_guidance: Run up as hard as during 400 track repeat
hill_repeats.notes: Strengthens quadriceps. Less impact than flat running. If marathon has downhill (like Boston), do 2 up to 1 down ratio. Don't overdo downhill to avoid injury. Can substitute for intervals if hilly marathon course.

intervals.description: 800m repeats at faster-than-marathon pace, every third Thursday
intervals.workout_structure: Run 800m at faster-than-marathon pace, rest by jogging/walking 400m, repeat
intervals.pace_guidance: Consider Yasso Repeats: use same numbers as marathon time (e.g., 3:00 marathoner does 800s in 3:00)
intervals.notes: Long repeats (800, 1600+) work better than short repeats (200, 400) for marathon training

tempo_run.description: Continuous run building to near 10K race pace in middle, every third Thursday
tempo_run.workout_structure: 30-40min tempo: 10-15min easy warmup, 10-20min gradual build to peak, 5-10min easy cooldown. 45min tempo: extend middle portion.
tempo_run.pace_guidance: Near 10K race pace at peak. Pace you could race flat-out for ~1 hour. Peak speed ~2/3 into workout for few minutes only.
tempo_run.notes: Buildup gradual not sudden. Not punishing - finish refreshed. Can do on road, trails, track. Better solo than with group.

easy_run.description: Comparatively easy pace on Mondays and Wednesdays
easy_run.notes: As weekend mileage builds, weekday mileage builds. Run slightly more miles during week than weekend long runs.

rest.description: Complete rest even for advanced runners
rest.notes: Friday designated rest day to gather forces for hard weekend. Muscles regenerate 24-72 hours between hard exercise. Need rest to run hard. Can take extra rest if needed (cold, late night, sick child). If tired from weekend, take Monday off or cut Wednesday.

adaptation_guidelines.scheduling_flexibility: Can skip occasional workout or juggle schedule but do not cheat on long runs.
adaptation_guidelines.cross_training_note: No cross-training scheduled. If needed/desired for injury avoidance, can substitute aerobic workout for Monday or Wednesday. Same duration as scheduled run. Don't make it hard. Friday not good for cross-training.
adaptation_guidelines.race_flexibility: Half marathon in Week 9 suggested to assess fitness, but not magic to that distance or week. Advanced runners should know how to make minor modifications.
adaptation_guidelines.speedwork_requirement: Must be familiar with speedwork before starting this program. Do not begin speedwork in marathon program if never done before.

templates.name: Hal Higdon Advanced 2 Marathon
templates.author: Hal Higdon
templates.description: The toughest program offered. Progressive buildup starting at 10 miles, three 20-milers, TWO days of speedwork per week. Only for hard-core runners with speedwork background.

prerequisites: Familiar with speedwork - do NOT begin speedwork in marathon program if never done before
Background in this demanding type of training
May not even be suitable for seasoned runners with 10-20 marathons
Not for first marathon - wait several marathons

key_principles: Most difficult program - high mileage + three 20-milers + TWO speedwork days
Long runs 30-90+ seconds slower than marathon pace
More training at marathon pace (Saturdays before Sunday long runs)
Speedwork Tuesday AND Thursday (hill repeats, intervals, tempo runs)
Do NOT run long runs at marathon pace - adds too much stress with two speed sessions
3/1 training strategy for most experienced runners
Every third week is stepback

long_run.description: Key weekend workout from 10 to 20 miles
long_run.pace_guidance: 30 to 90+ seconds per mile slower than marathon pace. Physiological benefits at 90-120 minutes regardless of speed. CRITICAL for advanced runners doing speedwork during week.
long_run.notes: 3/1 optional: first 3/4 easy, final 1/4 somewhat faster (not race pace). Only once every three weekends. Better too slow than too fast.

pace_run.pace_guidance: The pace you plan to run in marathon (e.g., 9:09/mile for 4:00 marathon)
pace_run.notes: Most Saturday runs at race pace OR some Tuesdays/Thursdays for shorter pace runs

hill_repeats.description: Hill training scheduled every third Thursday
hill_repeats.workout_structure: Select ~1/4 mile hill. Run up hard (like 400m track repeat). Jog back down. Repeat until finished.
hill_repeats.pace_guidance: Run up as hard as during 400 track repeat
hill_repeats.notes: Strengthens quadriceps. Less impact. If hilly marathon (like Boston), do 2 up to 1 down ratio. Can substitute for intervals if hilly course.

intervals.workout_structure: Run 800m at faster-than-marathon pace, rest by jogging/walking 400m, repeat
intervals.pace_guidance: Consider Yasso Repeats: use same numbers as marathon time (e.g., 3:00 marathoner does 800s in 3:00)
intervals.notes: Long repeats (800, 1600+) work better than short for marathon

tempo_run.description: Continuous run building to near 10K race pace in middle
tempo_run.workout_structure: 30-40min: 10-15min easy warmup, 10-20min gradual build to peak, 5-10min easy cooldown. 45-50min: extend middle portion.
tempo_run.pace_guidance: Near 10K race pace at peak. Pace you could race flat-out for ~1 hour. Peak speed ~2/3 into workout for few minutes only.
tempo_run.notes: Buildup gradual. Not punishing - finish refreshed. Can do on road, trails, track. Better solo.

easy_run.description: Comparatively easy pace on Mondays and Wednesdays
easy_run.notes: As weekend builds, weekday builds. Run only slightly more miles during week than weekend long runs.

rest.description: Complete rest even for Advanced 2 runners
rest.notes: Friday designated rest to gather forces for hard weekend. Muscles regenerate 24-72 hours between hard exercise. Need rest to run hard. Can take extra if needed. If tired from weekend, take Monday off or cut Wednesday.

adaptation_guidelines.scheduling_flexibility: Can skip occasional workout or juggle schedule but do not cheat on long runs.
adaptation_guidelines.cross_training_note: No cross-training scheduled. If needed/desired, can substitute aerobic workout for Monday or Wednesday. Same duration as scheduled run. Don't make it hard. Friday not good for cross-training.
adaptation_guidelines.speedwork_requirement: MUST be familiar with speedwork before starting. Do NOT begin speedwork in marathon program if never done before. This is the most demanding program.
adaptation_guidelines.warning: May not be suitable even for seasoned runners with 10-20 marathons. Only for hard-core runners willing to take it to the limit.
